simplified_text:
If you work thirty hours a week sending emails and going to meetings, your boss will realize that you need to say no to some things and simplify others. This might make things a bit harder for everyone, but the main goal of a business is to create value, not to make life easy for employees.

If you’re your own boss, looking at how much time you spend on tasks will show you how little value you’re actually creating. These numbers can help you feel confident about cutting back on activities that waste your time. Without this info, it’s tough to say no to any opportunity that might seem good. You might think, “I have to be on Twitter!” or “I need to keep my Facebook active!” Saying no to these feels lazy, but if you focus on balancing shallow tasks with deeper work, you can feel better about managing your time. This way, you can still explore opportunities while making sure you have enough time for the important work that helps your business grow.

Sometimes, when you ask your boss how much time should be spent on shallow work, the answer might be clear. No boss will say, “You should spend all your time on shallow tasks!” But they might suggest you do just enough shallow work to get by. If that’s the case, it means your job doesn’t support deeper work, which is important for success today. You should thank your boss for the feedback and start thinking about finding a new job that values deeper work.
